entities.name: ElizaOS
entities.description: ElizaOS is a project preparing for a significant token migration. It is involved in technical development with feature additions and bug fixes. The project has a token migration underway from $AI16Z to $ElizaOS with a 1:6 conversion ratio.

entities.name: $AI16Z
entities.description: A cryptocurrency token involved in a migration process to the $ElizaOS token.

entities.name: $ElizaOS
entities.description: A cryptocurrency token that is the target of a migration from the $AI16Z token. It has a 1:6 conversion ratio in the migration.

entities.name: Binance
entities.description: A cryptocurrency exchange platform that has had its CEO mentioned in relation to the ElizaOS project. It is also mentioned in the context of potentially supporting the new $ElizaOS token.

entities.name: CZ
entities.description: The CEO of Binance, who made a post related to ElizaOS. Mentioned in discussions within the ElizaOS community.

entities.name: Discord
entities.description: A communication platform used by the ElizaOS community for discussions and sharing information. It features various channels for different topics such as discussions, technical development, and partnerships.

entities.name: Phantom
entities.description: A cryptocurrency wallet recommended for users to migrate tokens to, specifically for self-custody after transferring from CEXs. It is described as a good wallet to hold $AI16Z before migrating to $ElizaOS.

entities.name: Metamask
entities.description: A cryptocurrency wallet recommended for users to migrate tokens to, specifically for self-custody after transferring from CEXs. It is mentioned as a suitable wallet for holding $AI16Z before migrating to $ElizaOS.

entities.name: Streamdown
entities.description: A technology or feature being integrated into the ElizaOS ecosystem, focusing on enhancing the UI experience for AI responses with modern rendering capabilities.

entities.name: MCP
entities.description: Stands for Model Control Protocol. It is an architecture discussed within the ElizaOS project, distinguishing between clients (such as claude code, cursor, codex) and servers (eliza mcp).

entities.name: claude code
entities.description: Mentioned as a client within the MCP architecture of the ElizaOS project. It is part of the technical discussions.

entities.name: cursor
entities.description: Mentioned as a client within the MCP architecture of the ElizaOS project. It is part of the technical discussions.

entities.name: codex
entities.description: Mentioned as a client within the MCP architecture of the ElizaOS project. It is part of the technical discussions.

entities.name: plugin-telegram
entities.description: A plugin for the ElizaOS project that is undergoing technical development, including refactoring attempts and deployment challenges. It is mentioned in the context of both cloud deployments and local functionality.

entities.name: DigitalOcean
entities.description: A cloud hosting provider where users have experienced difficulty deploying the plugin-telegram. It is mentioned as a platform for hosting agents and services.

entities.name: wuhuoqiu
entities.description: A user whose Twitter/X post was shared within the ElizaOS community. Their post was mentioned alongside a comment about the potential for randomness in short-term observations.

entities.name: Twitter/X
entities.description: A social media platform where posts from Binance CEO CZ and user wuhuoqiu were shared within the ElizaOS community. Used for external mentions and discussions.

entities.name: Solfare
entities.description: A platform or exchange where users hold $AI16Z tokens. Questions were raised about whether $AI16Z on Solfare would auto-migrate to ElizaOS.

entities.name: Bybit
entities.description: A centralized exchange (CEX) from which users need to transfer $AI16Z tokens to self-custody wallets to participate in the migration to $ElizaOS.

entities.name: Railway
entities.description: A cloud hosting platform mentioned in relation to deployment challenges for plugin-telegram and limitations with FTP uploads for large databases. Alternatives were suggested.

entities.name: OpenAI
entities.description: A provider of AI models, with users experiencing context size limitations when using their services with large databases (1GB+).

entities.name: Layer One X
entities.description: An entity that reached out to ElizaOS with a partnership proposal. The proposal includes offerings such as liquidity provision, cross-chain launch capabilities, and exchange listing access.

entities.name: xiaozhi-esp32
entities.description: A GitHub project related to hardware integration that ElizaOS is exploring for potential partnership opportunities.

entities.name: Hetzner
entities.description: A hosting provider suggested as an alternative for agents with large databases, particularly for users who require FTP access.

entities.name: OVH VPSes
entities.description: A hosting provider recommended as an alternative for agents with large databases, offering Virtual Private Servers (VPS) and FTP access.

entities.name: WholesaleInternet
entities.description: A hosting provider suggested as an alternative for agents with large databases, offering solutions potentially suitable for large database hosting.

entities.name: BuyVM
entities.description: A hosting provider recommended as an alternative for agents with large databases, suitable for users requiring robust hosting solutions.

entities.name: Postgres
entities.description: A database management system mentioned in the context of hosting solutions for agents. It is suggested for use with dump uploads or custom images for platforms like Railway.

entities.name: pglite
entities.description: A database-related component or technology mentioned in relation to creating custom images for platforms like Railway, specifically for hosting agents with large databases.

entities.name: Microsoft
entities.description: A company whose spec-kit framework was used in a refactoring attempt by a developer on the ElizaOS project. The attempt involved challenges and was eventually rolled back.

entities.name: spec-kit
entities.description: A framework developed by Microsoft that was used in a refactoring attempt by a developer within the ElizaOS project. The developer rolled back the changes due to difficulties encountered.
